item.title: Carnarvon growers enjoy massive mango season, bringing prices down for consumers
item.description: A WA mango grower is pleasantly surprised to find a crop full of massive mangoes, as big as a bowling ball.

item.title: Australian Open qualifying: Cruz Hewitt knocked out in first round, Storm Hunter returns with a win
item.description: It is the second year in a row Hewitt has been knocked out in the first round of qualifying, but the match against a much higher-ranked opponent can only do good things for him.

item.title: Jasper Jones author Craig Silvey faces Fremantle court over alleged child exploitation offences
item.description: One of Australia's most renowned authors, Craig Silvey, faces court after he allegedly distributed child exploitation material.

item.title: Venus Williams exits Hobart International after straight-sets loss to Tatjana Maria
item.description: After being awarded a wildcard at the age of 45, seven-time major singles champion Venus Williams falls in the opening round in Hobart.

item.title: Ruffy community determined to rebuild after Longwood bushfire destroys Victorian town
item.description: Residents in the central Victorian community of Ruffy say they are determined to rebuild after a bushfire destroyed most buildings in the small community.

item.title: Sydney Festival show asses.masses combines participatory theatre and the social fabric of playing video games together
item.description: Theatre makers Patrick Blenkarn and Milton Lim have built a game to be played socially in an auditorium, with a single player leading a group of donkeys on a journey of discovery.

item.description: News from the world of finance and business. Top stories in text, video and audio. Business video news bulletin. Features and analysis.

item.title: Public transport bypassed in Labor's Mount Barker re-election promises
item.description: Labor today announced a $200 million investment in Mount Barker as part of its bid to win the seat of Kavel, but while some of those initiatives have been welcomed, there was a glaring omission in public transport solutions.

item.title: Liberals divided over Labor's plan to outlaw inciting racial hatred
item.description: After weeks criticising the Albanese government over the Bondi attack and issues around antisemitism, the Coalition is split over whether proposed solutions are at odds with its interests in preserving freedom of speech.

item.title: Global financial markets to face major test next week as central bankers support Powell
item.description: Lisa Cook vs the US government will hit the courts next week. The case comes as Australia's Reserve Bank governor, Michele Bullock, signs a letter in support of US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell, who is facing a criminal investigation in the United States.

item.title: Around 2,500 reportedly killed in protests as Donald Trump tells Iranians 'help is on its way'
item.description: Activists say around 2,500 people have been killed in protests against the country's ruling Islamic regime.

item.title: Prosecutors seek death penalty for Yoon Suk Yeol in South Korea after martial law call
item.description: Yoon Suk Yeol faces several criminal charges related to his call to impose martial law and other criminal cases related to his time in office.

item.title: Eloise Worledge investigation overlooked a known rapist in Beaumaris
item.description: As police up the reward to $1 million for information that will lead to the remains of missing school girl Eloise Worledge, questions remain about why police disregarded a known rapist in their investigation.

item.title: Documents reveal tensions over Kunanyi/Mt Wellington access plans debate
item.description: Loved by bushwalkers and tourists, a sacred Aboriginal site, and with weather conditions that can quickly deteriorate, Hobart's Kunanyi/Mount Wellington is a challenge to manage — and a government review of how that is done is being met with concerns.

item.title: Rare verified footage of Iran's protests posted online shows how the movement started and how it is growing
item.description: The first embers of the Iranian protests started in a mobile phone market, spreading to every corner of the country as the Revolutionary Guard struggled to regain control.

item.title: Racism targeting migrant truck drivers rampant amid regulatory gaps
item.description: Some Indian truck drivers have copped so much racist abuse they have stopped using their CB radios.

item.title: A tearful premier and 'Moscow on the Torrens': How to lose a writers' week in six days
item.description: The removal and subsequent handling of Randa Abdel-Fattah's rescinded invitation to Adelaide Writers' Week led to the event's cancellation, with more than 180 authors pulling out and its own director issuing a pointed and very public resignation. Where does the festival go from here?

item.description: With the 2026 Australian Open just around the corner here's everything you need to know about the tournament.

item.description: The ABC can reveal a neurosurgeon specialising in spinal surgery is among five people facing serious charges over a Queensland scheme allegedly involving kickbacks for medical devices.

item.description: Residents in low-lying areas surrounding the Mackenzie River are being warned to leave now due to dangerous flooding.

item.description: The chihuahua-cross was rescued by Vinnies volunteers who named the puppy "Vinnie". The charity says it is rare but unfortunately not unheard of for live animals to be donated.

item.title: There is now a strong likelihood Donald Trump will order his military option of choice on Iran

item.description: Bernard Tomic was brushed past by Britain's Arthur Fery in their second round match, while Olivia Gadecki was beaten by Sloane Stephens.

item.description: The Australian Conservation Foundation says tens of thousands of hectares of land were approved for clearing last year, double that of 2024, putting already endangered species at further risk.

item.description: The 20-year-old world number 204, who also has a wildcard at the upcoming Australian Open, won the match against the world number 72 6-4, 6-1.

item.description: No Limit boss George Rose says the doorway to the world will open for the winner of the Nikita Tszyu and Michael Zerafa grudge boxing showdown.

item.description: Police are urging Canberrans not to touch suspicious objects after pipe bombs were discovered in Belconnen.

item.description: From 6,000 applications each year, only about 300 make the cut to travel down to Antarctica and experience a workplace like no other.

item.description: Severe thunderstorms and flooding rain are expected to ease the short-term fire threat, while Queensland continues to be drenched from ex-Tropical Cyclone Koji.

item.description: Australia's rental market is "starting to rebalance" with prices flat in some capital cities but affordability remains a concern, according to Domain, which says an annual salary of $100,000 is needed to live comfortably.

item.description: Gulgong went 18 months without a GP clinic. It has now reopened, giving residents a reprieve from travelling hundreds of kilometres to see a doctor.

item.description: Thousands of people present to Australian hospitals each year for ladder and roof falls, with doctors urging caution — particularly for ageing Australians.

item.description: From a CIA-led coup to a hostage crisis and air strikes, here are some of the defining moments in seven decades of relations between the United States and Iran.

item.description: Communities in Queensland's central highlands region remain on high alert today as major flooding continues along the Mackenzie River.

item.description: Despite the NT government signing on to establish 20 Aboriginal Law and Justice Groups by 2027, just five are up and running with less than 12 months to go.

item.description: Daniel Sanders says he has broken his collarbone and sternum in a crash on stage 10 of the Dakar Rally, but vows to finish the last three stages.

item.description: The US State Department will suspend processing of immigrant visas for people from 75 countries, including Fiji, Cambodia, Thailand, Somalia and Brazil, from January 21.

item.description: Having repeatedly lost mobile coverage during recent bushfires, local councils and volunteer brigades are paying for expensive satellite units to maintain critical communications.

item.description: WA's environmental regulator is investigating an alleged breach of Alcoa's state-imposed mining conditions which, if proven, would make it illegal for the company to continue some of its mining operations.

item.title: Australia's vet access deserts where an hour's drive is the difference in life and death
item.description: More than 250,000 people do not have ready access to a vet in Australia, and according to the industry, it is not completely down to a shortage. It is also a distribution issue, which is putting biosecurity at risk.

item.description: A spectacular bowling effort in the final overs and a key contribution from Marnus Labuschagne help the Brisbane Heat to an upset win over the Hobart Hurricanes to keep their BBL finals hopes alive.

item.description: New techniques and technology are allowing southern NSW grain growers to produce a harvest, despite significantly below-average rainfall.

item.description: Federal Liberals are discovering the price of having been so brazen in their politicisation of the Bondi terror attack and many appear to have buyers' remorse.

item.description: Fearing more lives will be lost, Kimberley Aboriginal leaders call on the WA government to release updates on parliamentary and coronial recommendations into youth suicide.

item.title: Astronauts return from ISS with sick crew member
item.description: Sarah Ferguson presents Australia's premier daily current affairs program, delivering agenda-setting public affairs journalism and interviews that hold the powerful to account. Plus political analysis from Laura Tingle.

item.title: NASA's Crew 11 Dragon splashdown upon returning to Earth
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: More than 4.7m social media accounts closed in two days after ban began, data reveals
item.description: More than 4.7 million Australian social media accounts have been deactivated since laws banning children aged under 16 took effect in December, according to data released by the government.

item.title: Antidepressants less effective for many living with atypical depression, new study finds
item.description: A major Australian study finds standard antidepressants are not effective for about 20 per cent of people, who may need alternative treatments.

item.title: Hong Kong fire at Wang Fuk Court killed 168 people, local authorities announce
item.description: The final death toll is seven higher than previously reported and comes months after the fire tore through the apartment complex.

item.title: Pulp agree to Adelaide Festival show after apology to Randa Abdel-Fattah
item.description: In a social media post, British indie band Pulp says it had previously informed festival organisers of its decision to withdraw but were asked "to delay an announcement while [organisers] sought to resolve this crisis for all sides", and it had now agreed to perform.

item.title: Trump threatens to invoke Insurrection Act over Minnesota anti-ICE protests
item.description: Such a move would allow the president to deploy troops to quell persistent protests in the city of Minneapolis, where two shootings connected to immigration crackdowns are fuelling public anger.

item.title: Great Ocean Road flash flooding leaves beach towns to count the cost
item.description: The Lorne caravan park will be closed for weeks after record-breaking rains turned into "terrifying" floodwaters, sweeping cars into the ocean and inundating holiday parks along Victoria's Great Ocean Road.

item.title: Australia's notorious Bass Strait was once conquered by two men in a 4.5m dinghy
item.description: With whisky and lollies for sustenance and pigeons their only means of communication, Steve Harris and Doug Fleming crossed Bass Strait in a 4.5m dinghy in 1974.

item.title: Weekly news quiz: An early departure, an Aussie Golden Globe win and a space mission
item.description: Test your knowledge of this week's news cycle here.

item.title: Heated Rivalry and growing sports romance genre can teach lessons about queer inclusion
item.description: Heated Rivalry has become a massive global hit, but can the steamy ice hockey romance, and other queer love stories, help create more inclusive spaces in the real sporting world?

item.title: Fight brewing on national gun reform as states splinter on party lines
item.description: A split is emerging at a state level over the government's plan to establish a national gun buyback scheme following the Bondi terror attack.

item.title: What is in the government's new hate speech laws?
item.description: Parliament will return early next week to debate new hate speech laws. But what exactly does the legislation include?

item.title: Energy giant AGL offers cash for conservation amid grid strains
item.description: In a move labelled a sign of the times, energy firm AGL was last week offering customers money to cut use during a heatwave.

item.title: Hundreds of satellite images capture Victoria's destructive bushfires erupting
item.description: Hundreds of images captured by an orbiting weather satellite, and stitched together by the ABC, show the scale and destructive force of the Victorian bushfires.

item.title: Former Whyalla steelworks owner's $18.5 million royalties debt revealed
item.description: The former owner of the Whyalla steelworks, Sanjeev Gupta's OneSteel Manufacturing, owed $18.5 million in royalties when it was forced into administration last year, the ABC can reveal.

item.title: Locals oppose tearing down of Bondi terror attack bridge at Waverley Council meeting
item.description: Waverley Council held an extraordinary meeting last night, but the future of the footbridge used by the Bondi gunmen remains undecided.

item.title: Calls for greater public awareness about battery dangers after fires at regional landfill sites
item.description: People are being urged to dispose of their batteries properly, after a series of fires at landfills across New South Wales.

item.title: Queensland woman wakes up to find carpet python on top of her
item.description: It's fair to say when a Brisbane resident woke up to discover a carpet python curled up on top of her, she was rattled.

item.title: Rockhampton and Gulf Country communities brace for possible flooding
item.description: Rockhampton is bracing for possible flooding while communities in the already-sodden Gulf Country fear they may be isolated for "a long time to come" as ex-Tropical Cyclone Koji threatens more rain.

item.title: Venezuelan families wait in hope for release of political prisoners
item.description: Venezuela's new leader says political prisoners are being freed, but hundreds remain jailed, with families clinging to hope that America's intervention and ongoing pressure will eventually secure their loved ones' release

item.title: Who could lead Iran if the Islamic Republic falls?
item.description: Names frequently raised include an exiled prince, a former president, and the leader of a leftist movement, but experts say no single figure has the power and legitimacy to take control alone.

item.title: Child slapped in the face among inappropriate educator discipline exposed in Canberra childcare document dump
item.description: Documents detailing five years' worth of childcare breaches in the ACT reveal cases of educators slapping children, forcibly shaking them, throwing them, and possessing child exploitation material.

item.title: Sydney Fish Market vendors to prepare for 'teething problems', ferry wharf still to come
item.description: More than $600 million over budget, the Sydney Fish Market will open its doors, but traders and visitors are being warned to prepare for teething issues.

item.title: Investigation proposes ban that could see high-speed waterski racing leave Murray River
item.description: A report into the safety of ski racing on rivers is proposing to ban river racing events and limit speeds following multiple fatalities in recent years.

item.title: Finn Allen smashes maiden BBL century as Perth Scorchers book finals spot
item.description: Finn Allen saves his best ever BBL innings for when it matters most as the Perth Scorchers out-duel the Melbourne Renegades.

item.title: 'Apocalyptic Christian cult' Shincheonji using 'special force teams' to spread across the country
item.description: Documents leaked to the ABC reveal an "apocalyptic Christian cult" is targeting Ballarat, Bendigo, Geelong and Darwin.

item.title: Hamnet's historical figures are brought to life, only to be robbed of depth
item.description: Chloé Zhao's retelling of the life of William Shakespeare is on the fast track to the Academy Awards, but at times feels like Oscar-bait.

item.title: The NT's last private obstetrician walks away as maternity services face collapse
item.description: A growing number of women in the Northern Territory are travelling interstate to give birth — or leaving the territory altogether — following the sudden closure of the only private hospital maternity ward. Now, the NT's last private obstetrician is closing her practice.

item.title: Live updates: Wall Street rallies on Taiwan chips, AUD almost to 67 US cents
item.description: The Australian dollar jumps again on potentially more dovish policy from the US Federal Reserve, while Taiwan and the US have struck a major semiconductor deal. Follow the day's events and insights as they happen with our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

item.title: European troops won't change Trump's ambition for Greenland, says White House
item.description: As European countries send small numbers of troops to Greenland, the White House says their presence will not affect US President Donald Trump's ambitions for the island.

item.title: Storm Hunter fights tears after overcoming injury heartache to reach Australian Open main draw
item.description: Storm Hunter books her spot in the main draw of the Australian Open — something that was inconceivable last year as she battled injuries that left her in tears mid-match.

item.title: Queensland family demands answers after grandmother dies from 'preventable' bloodstream infection
item.description: Struggling to find answers about what happened in the week leading up to her death in hospital, Sue Smith's loved ones say they want hospitals to put more resources into investigating these types of incidents.

item.title: City of Canning Mayor Patrick Hall wins defamation case over ratepayer's social media posts
item.description: City of Canning Mayor Patrick Hall is awarded a quarter of a million dollars in a lengthy defamation fight with one of his own constituents over a series of social media posts.

item.title: Christmas Island welcomes 'twice-in-a-decade' return of millions of baby red crabs
item.description: Wildlife officials on one of Australia's most remote territories are welcoming the final chapter of its famous red crab migration, the return to shore of millions of baby crabs.

item.title: Winemakers hit hard losing homes, vineyards and stocks in Victorian fires
item.description: Two wineries in the Strathbogie Ranges have lost a combined 150 hectares of vines, 3,000 sheep and three homes in the Victorian fires.

item.title: Machado greets supporters outside White House
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: Venezuelan opposition leader Machado presents her Nobel Peace Prize to Trump
item.description: Maria Corina Machado says she presented Donald Trump with her Nobel Peace Prize medal during a meeting in Washington earlier today but did not say whether he accepted it.

item.title: Ralph Fiennes says new film 28 Years Later: The Bone Temple is a story of 'monstrosity and empathy'
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: NSW government unveils $3 billion plan to combat debris balls washing up on Sydney beaches
item.description: The NSW Environment Protection Authority identified the Malabar wastewater treatment system as the origin of the debris balls plaguing beaches in Sydney.

item.title: Paul Mescal on why we keep coming back to Shakespeare over 400 years later
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: Farm workers chase $260,000 in unpaid wages, some from major supermarket suppliers
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: 75pc of feedlot cattle now have access to shade, industry says
item.description: Once seen as barren landscapes, feedlots across Australia have been reshaping their image. With industry encouraging its operators to install shade, uptake has been widespread.

item.title: Nikita Tszyu and Michael Zerafa separated by security in fiery weigh-in clash ahead of boxing clash
item.description: There is no love lost between Nikita Tszyu and Michael Zerafa as they meet for one final time before their much-anticipated fight in Brisbane.

item.title: WA farmers grapple with three-month BOM radar outage ahead of planting season
item.description: A Kimberley pastoralist says the radar will be of little use by the time it comes back online at the end of the wet season.

item.title: US says Iran has halted executions but 'all options remain on the table'
item.description: The White House says it will hold off on military action in Iran after the regime halted executions, but "all options remain on the table" if the killing of protesters continues.

item.title: Artificial reefs among options in coastal SA town's erosion battle
item.description: As erosion threatens roads and even homes in Robe in South Australia, artificial reefs and other options are on the table to fight back.

item.title: Machado says she presented Trump with her Nobel Peace Prize medal
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: Walgett residents furious after 100-year-old Anzac statue smashed
item.description: Residents of a north-west NSW town are angry and heartbroken after a statue with more than 100 years of history was unceremoniously shattered in the middle of the night.

item.title: Daniel Sanders shrugs off broken collarbone to complete 11th stage of Dakar Rally
item.description: Daniel Sanders returns to complete the 11th stage of the Dakar Rally less than 24 hours after suffering a broken collarbone and sternum.

item.title: World champion Shelley Taylor-Smith runs swim group for women at Mettams Pool
item.description: The group meets twice a week, with some members stepping out of their comfort zones to train for the Busselton Jetty swim.

item.title: Twenty-four parkruns in 24 hours no sweat for Albany runner Ben Castlehow
item.description: An Albany man runs roughly three marathons in laps of a hilly parkrun to raise funds for a charity that helped him through a tough time.

item.title: US legal case against Amazon Prime subscription service leads to cheque in the mail for Australian
item.description: Australian woman Laura Wells was confused to find an "official-looking letter" from the US with a $51 reimbursement, but it turns out it was legitimate.

item.title: Four more pipe bombs found in north-west Canberra as police investigation continues
item.description: ACT police say they have found four more pipe bombs in the Belconnen area, after 11 explosive devices were discovered close to Lake Ginninderra over the previous two days.

item.title: Office workers driven batty by relentless computer updates
item.description: Have you turned on your work computer after a holiday, only to find so many updates and security enhancements that you may as well take a break before you start?

item.title: North Queensland redclaw farmer looks to science to meet overwhelming resturant demand
item.description: The freshwater crayfish is becoming more popular in restaurants across Australia, but the industry faces challenges boosting production as more farmers retire.

item.title: Castlemaine family flees Wye River flood days after Harcourt bushfire evacuation
item.description: A family holidaying at Wye River on the Great Ocean Road have been lucky to escape flash flooding less than a week after catastrophic fires drove them from their central Victorian home.

item.title: Trump administration announces 'major sporting event' exemptions from US visa ban
item.description: The Trump administration reveals the sporting events that athletes, coaches and support staff can attend in the US despite recent visa bans.

item.title: Australian who escaped Iran recalls protesters being shot and says the crackdown is 'different this time'
item.description: On a visit to his home town outside Tehran, this Iranian Australian joined the protests last Thursday night, then the regime's suppression methods turned from tear gas to live fire.

item.title: Campers told to reconsider travel as severe weather lashes NSW south coast
item.description: Campers have been evacuated from low-lying areas as damaging wet weather makes its way along the NSW south coast.

item.title: Engaged Aussie couple Inglis and Kubler through to Australian Open main draw
item.description: Maddison Inglis and Jason Kubler were able to celebrate their Australian Open qualifications together in a heartwarming moment.

item.title: Perth Glory ALW coach Stephen Peters calls out lack of investment in women's A-League football
item.description: In recent years, the Glory's women's side has been Perth's saving grace, as the men's team suffered back-to-back wooden-spoon finishes.

item.title: Smoke warning in outer west Melbourne after fast-moving grassfire approaches homes
item.description: Dozens of firefighters worked to contain the fast-moving blaze, which burned through a paddock and a pile of tyres as it approached homes near Melton.

item.title: Convicted fraudster David Prince-Popovich registered as Tasmanian lobbyist
item.description: David Prince-Popovich registered as an official lobbyist in Tasmania despite being a convicted fraudster, against the register's rules.

item.title: Flooding in NSW town of Eden on 15th January, 2026
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.
